The **Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms**
([French](/wiki/French_language "French language"): _La Charte canadienne des
droits et libertés_), in Canada often simply the **Charter** , is a [bill of
rights](/wiki/Bill_of_rights "Bill of rights") entrenched in the [Constitution
of Canada](/wiki/Constitution_of_Canada "Constitution of Canada"). It forms
the first part of the [Constitution Act, 1982](/wiki/Constitution_Act,_1982
"Constitution Act, 1982"). The Charter guarantees certain
[political](/wiki/Politics_of_Canada "Politics of Canada") rights to Canadian
citizens and [civil rights](/wiki/Civil_rights "Civil rights") of everyone in
[Canada](/wiki/Canada "Canada") from the policies and actions of all areas and
levels of the [government](/wiki/Government_of_Canada "Government of Canada").
It is designed to unify [Canadians](/wiki/Canadians "Canadians") around a set
of principles that embody those rights. The Charter was signed into law by
[Queen Elizabeth II of Canada](/wiki/Monarchy_of_Canada "Monarchy of Canada")
on April 17, 1982, along with the rest of the Act.

The Charter was preceded by the [Canadian Bill of
Rights](/wiki/Canadian_Bill_of_Rights "Canadian Bill of Rights"), which was
enacted in 1960. However, the Bill of Rights is only a federal
[statute](/wiki/Statute "Statute"), rather than a constitutional document. As
a federal statute, it can be amended through the ordinary legislative process
and has no application to provincial laws. The Supreme Court of Canada also
narrowly interpreted the Bill of Rights and the Court was reluctant to declare
laws inoperative.[1] The relative ineffectiveness of the Canadian Bill of
Rights motivated many to improve rights protections in Canada. The movement
for [human rights](/wiki/Human_right "Human right") and freedoms that emerged
after [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II") also wanted to
entrench the principles enunciated in the [Universal Declaration of Human
Rights](/wiki/Universal_Declaration_of_Human_Rights "Universal Declaration of
Human Rights").[2] The British Parliament formally enacted the Charter as a
part of the [Canada Act 1982](/wiki/Canada_Act_1982 "Canada Act 1982") at the
request of the [Parliament of Canada](/wiki/Parliament_of_Canada "Parliament
of Canada") in 1982, the result of the efforts of the government of [Prime
Minister](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Canada "Prime Minister of Canada") [Pierre
Trudeau](/wiki/Pierre_Trudeau "Pierre Trudeau").

One of the most notable effects of the adoption of the Charter was to greatly
expand the scope of [judicial review](/wiki/Judicial_review "Judicial
review"), because the Charter is more explicit with respect to the guarantee
of rights and the role of judges in enforcing them than was the Bill of
Rights. The [courts](/wiki/Court_system_of_Canada "Court system of Canada"),
when confronted with violations of Charter rights, have struck down
unconstitutional federal and provincial statutes and regulations or parts of
statutes and regulations, as they did when [Canadian case
law](/wiki/Law_of_Canada "Law of Canada") was primarily concerned with
resolving issues of [federalism](/wiki/Canadian_federalism "Canadian
federalism"). The Charter, however, granted new powers to the courts to
enforce remedies that are more creative and to exclude more evidence in
trials. These powers are greater than what was typical under the [common
law](/wiki/Common_law "Common law") and under a system of government that,
influenced by Canada's parent country the [United
Kingdom](/wiki/United_Kingdom "United Kingdom"), was based upon [Parliamentary
supremacy](/wiki/Parliamentary_supremacy "Parliamentary supremacy"). As a
result, the Charter has attracted both broad support from a majority of the
Canadian electorate and criticisms by opponents of increased [judicial
power](/wiki/Judicial_power "Judicial power"). The Charter only applies to
government laws and actions (including the laws and actions of federal,
provincial, and municipal governments and public school boards), and sometimes
to the common law, not to private activity.

Under the Charter, people physically present in Canada have numerous civil and
political rights. Most of the rights can be exercised by any legal person (the
Charter does not define the corporation as a "legal person"),[3] but a few of
the rights belong exclusively to natural persons, or (as in sections 3 and 6)
only to [citizens of Canada](/wiki/Canadian_nationality_law "Canadian
nationality law"). The rights are enforceable by the courts through [section
24](/wiki/Section_Twenty-four_of_the_Canadian_Charter_of_Rights_and_Freedoms
"Section Twenty-four of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms") of the
Charter, which allows courts discretion to award remedies to those whose
rights have been denied. This section also allows courts to exclude evidence
in trials if the evidence was acquired in a way that conflicts with the
Charter and might damage the reputation of the justice system. [Section
32](/wiki/Section_Thirty-two_of_the_Canadian_Charter_of_Rights_and_Freedoms
"Section Thirty-two of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms") confirms
that the Charter is binding on the federal government, the territories under
its authority, and the provincial governments. The rights and freedoms
enshrined in 34 sections of the Charter include:

###
Exceptions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Canadian_Charter_of_Rights_and_Freedoms&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Exceptions")]

Precluding all the freedoms and forming the basis of the Charter, the [very
first
section](/wiki/Section_One_of_the_Canadian_Charter_of_Rights_and_Freedoms
"Section One of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms"), known as
_limitations clause_ , allows governments to justify certain infringements of
Charter rights. Every case in which a court discovers a violation of the
Charter would therefore require a section 1 analysis to determine if the law
can still be upheld. Infringements are upheld if the purpose for the
government action is to achieve what would be recognized as an urgent or
important objective in a free society, and if the infringement can be
"demonstrably justified." Section 1 has thus been used to uphold laws against
objectionable conduct such as [hate speech](/wiki/Hate_speech "Hate speech")
(e.g., in _[R. v. Keegstra](/wiki/R._v._Keegstra "R. v. Keegstra")_) and
[obscenity](/wiki/Obscenity "Obscenity") (e.g., in _[R. v.
Butler](/wiki/R._v._Butler "R. v. Butler")_). Section 1 also confirms that the
rights listed in the Charter are guaranteed.

In addition, some of these rights are also subjected to the _notwithstanding
clause_ ([section 33](/wiki/Section_Thirty-
three_of_the_Canadian_Charter_of_Rights_and_Freedoms "Section Thirty-three of
the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms")). The notwithstanding clause
authorizes governments to temporarily override the rights and freedoms in
sections 2 and 7–15 for up to five years, subject to renewal. The Canadian
federal government has never invoked it, and some have speculated that its use
would be politically costly.[4] In the past, the notwithstanding clause was
invoked routinely by the province of [Quebec](/wiki/Quebec "Quebec") (which
did not support the enactment of the Charter but is subject to it
nonetheless). The provinces of [Saskatchewan](/wiki/Saskatchewan
"Saskatchewan") and [Alberta](/wiki/Alberta "Alberta") have also invoked the
notwithstanding clause, to end a [strike](/wiki/Strike_action "Strike action")
and to protect an exclusively [heterosexual definition](/wiki/Same-
sex_marriage_in_Canada "Same-sex marriage in Canada") of marriage,[5]
respectively. (Note that Alberta's use of the notwithstanding clause is of no
force or effect, since the definition of marriage is federal not provincial
jurisdiction.)[6] The territory of Yukon also passed legislation once that
invoked the notwithstanding clause, but the legislation was never proclaimed
in force.[7]

### Fundamental
freedoms[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Canadian_Charter_of_Rights_and_Freedoms&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Fundamental freedoms")]

    

    [Section 2:](/wiki/Section_Two_of_the_Canadian_Charter_of_Rights_and_Freedoms "Section Two of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms") which lists what the Charter calls "fundamental freedoms" namely [freedom of conscience](/wiki/Freedom_of_conscience "Freedom of conscience"), [freedom of religion](/wiki/Freedom_of_religion "Freedom of religion"), [freedom of thought](/wiki/Freedom_of_thought "Freedom of thought"), [freedom of belief](/wiki/Freedom_of_belief "Freedom of belief"), [freedom of expression](/wiki/Freedom_of_expression "Freedom of expression"), [freedom of the press](/wiki/Freedom_of_the_press "Freedom of the press") and of other media of communication, [freedom of peaceful assembly](/wiki/Freedom_of_assembly "Freedom of assembly"), and [freedom of association](/wiki/Freedom_of_association "Freedom of association").

### Democratic
rights[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Canadian_Charter_of_Rights_and_Freedoms&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Democratic rights")]

Generally, the right to participate in political activities and the right to a
[democratic](/wiki/Democracy "Democracy") form of government are protected:

    

    [Section 3:](/wiki/Section_Three_of_the_Canadian_Charter_of_Rights_and_Freedoms "Section Three of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms") the right to [vote](/wiki/Voting "Voting") and to be eligible to serve as member of a [legislature](/wiki/Legislative_Assemblies_of_Canada%27s_provinces_and_territories "Legislative Assemblies of Canada's provinces and territories").
    [Section 4:](/wiki/Section_Four_of_the_Canadian_Charter_of_Rights_and_Freedoms "Section Four of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms") the maximum duration of legislatures is set at five years.
    [Section 5:](/wiki/Section_Five_of_the_Canadian_Charter_of_Rights_and_Freedoms "Section Five of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms") an annual sitting of legislatures is required as a minimum.

### Mobility
rights[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Canadian_Charter_of_Rights_and_Freedoms&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Mobility rights")]

    

    [Section 6](/wiki/Section_Six_of_the_Canadian_Charter_of_Rights_and_Freedoms "Section Six of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms"): protects the mobility rights of Canadian citizens which include the right to enter, remain in, and leave Canada. Citizens and Permanent Residents have the ability to move to and take up residence in any province to pursue gaining livelihood.

### Legal
rights[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Canadian_Charter_of_Rights_and_Freedoms&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Legal rights")]

Rights of people in dealing with the justice system and law enforcement are
protected, namely:

    

    [Section 7:](/wiki/Section_Seven_of_the_Canadian_Charter_of_Rights_and_Freedoms "Section Seven of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms") right to life, liberty, and security of the person.
    [Section 8:](/wiki/Section_Eight_of_the_Canadian_Charter_of_Rights_and_Freedoms "Section Eight of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms") freedom from unreasonable [search and seizure](/wiki/Search_and_seizure "Search and seizure").
    [Section 9:](/wiki/Section_Nine_of_the_Canadian_Charter_of_Rights_and_Freedoms "Section Nine of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms") freedom from arbitrary detention or imprisonment.
    [Section 10:](/wiki/Section_Ten_of_the_Canadian_Charter_of_Rights_and_Freedoms "Section Ten of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms") right to legal counsel and the guarantee of [habeas corpus](/wiki/Habeas_corpus "Habeas corpus").
    [Section 11:](/wiki/Section_Eleven_of_the_Canadian_Charter_of_Rights_and_Freedoms "Section Eleven of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms") rights in criminal and penal matters such as the right to be [presumed innocent](/wiki/Presumption_of_innocence "Presumption of innocence") until proven guilty.
    [Section 12:](/wiki/Section_Twelve_of_the_Canadian_Charter_of_Rights_and_Freedoms "Section Twelve of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms") right not to be subject to [cruel and unusual punishment](/wiki/Cruel_and_unusual_punishment "Cruel and unusual punishment").
    [Section 13:](/wiki/Section_Thirteen_of_the_Canadian_Charter_of_Rights_and_Freedoms "Section Thirteen of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms") rights against self-incrimination
    [Section 14:](/wiki/Section_Fourteen_of_the_Canadian_Charter_of_Rights_and_Freedoms "Section Fourteen of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms") rights to an interpreter in a court proceeding.

### Equality
rights[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Canadian_Charter_of_Rights_and_Freedoms&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Equality rights")]

    

    [Section 15:](/wiki/Section_Fifteen_of_the_Canadian_Charter_of_Rights_and_Freedoms "Section Fifteen of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms") equal treatment before and under the law, and equal protection and benefit of the law without discrimination.

### Language
rights[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Canadian_Charter_of_Rights_and_Freedoms&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Language rights")]

Generally, people have the right to use either the
[English](/wiki/English_language "English language") or [French
language](/wiki/French_language "French language") in communications with
Canada's federal government and certain provincial governments. Specifically,
the language laws in the Charter include:

    

    [Section 16:](/wiki/Section_Sixteen_of_the_Canadian_Charter_of_Rights_and_Freedoms "Section Sixteen of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms") English and French are the official languages of Canada and [New Brunswick](/wiki/New_Brunswick "New Brunswick").
    [Section 16.1:](/wiki/Section_Sixteen_One_of_the_Canadian_Charter_of_Rights_and_Freedoms "Section Sixteen One of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms") the English and French-speaking communities of New Brunswick have equal rights to [educational](/wiki/Education_in_Canada "Education in Canada") and [cultural](/wiki/Culture_of_Canada "Culture of Canada") institutions.
    [Section 17:](/wiki/Section_Seventeen_of_the_Canadian_Charter_of_Rights_and_Freedoms "Section Seventeen of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms") the right to use either official language in [Parliament](/wiki/Parliament_of_Canada "Parliament of Canada") or the New Brunswick legislature.
    [Section 18:](/wiki/Section_Eighteen_of_the_Canadian_Charter_of_Rights_and_Freedoms "Section Eighteen of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms") the statutes and proceedings of Parliament and the New Brunswick legislature are to be printed in both official languages.
    [Section 19:](/wiki/Section_Nineteen_of_the_Canadian_Charter_of_Rights_and_Freedoms "Section Nineteen of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms") both official languages may be used in federal and New Brunswick courts.
    [Section 20:](/wiki/Section_Twenty_of_the_Canadian_Charter_of_Rights_and_Freedoms "Section Twenty of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms") the right to communicate with and be served by the federal and New Brunswick governments in either official language.
    [Section 21:](/wiki/Section_Twenty-one_of_the_Canadian_Charter_of_Rights_and_Freedoms "Section Twenty-one of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms") other constitutional language rights outside the Charter regarding English and French are sustained.
    [Section 22:](/wiki/Section_Twenty-two_of_the_Canadian_Charter_of_Rights_and_Freedoms "Section Twenty-two of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms") existing rights to use languages besides English and French are not affected by the fact that only English and French have language rights in the Charter. (Hence, if there are any rights to use [Aboriginal](/wiki/Aboriginal_peoples_in_Canada "Aboriginal peoples in Canada") languages anywhere they would continue to exist, though they would have no direct protection under the Charter.)

### Minority language education
rights[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Canadian_Charter_of_Rights_and_Freedoms&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Minority language education rights")]

    

    [Section 23:](/wiki/Section_Twenty-three_of_the_Canadian_Charter_of_Rights_and_Freedoms "Section Twenty-three of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms") rights for certain citizens belonging to French and English speaking minority communities to be educated in their own language.

### Other
sections[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Canadian_Charter_of_Rights_and_Freedoms&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Other sections")]

Various provisions help to clarify how the Charter works in practice. These
include,

    

    [Section 25:](/wiki/Section_Twenty-five_of_the_Canadian_Charter_of_Rights_and_Freedoms "Section Twenty-five of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms") states that the Charter does not derogate existing Aboriginal rights and freedoms. Aboriginal rights, including treaty rights, receive more direct constitutional protection under [section 35](/wiki/Section_Thirty-five_of_the_Constitution_Act,_1982 "Section Thirty-five of the Constitution Act, 1982") of the Constitution Act, 1982.
    [Section 26:](/wiki/Section_Twenty-six_of_the_Canadian_Charter_of_Rights_and_Freedoms "Section Twenty-six of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms") clarifies that other rights and freedoms in Canada are not invalidated by the Charter.
    [Section 27:](/wiki/Section_Twenty-seven_of_the_Canadian_Charter_of_Rights_and_Freedoms "Section Twenty-seven of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms") requires the Charter to be interpreted in a [multicultural](/wiki/Multiculturalism "Multiculturalism") context.
    [Section 28:](/wiki/Section_Twenty-eight_of_the_Canadian_Charter_of_Rights_and_Freedoms "Section Twenty-eight of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms") states all Charter rights are guaranteed equally to men and women.
    [Section 29:](/wiki/Section_Twenty-nine_of_the_Canadian_Charter_of_Rights_and_Freedoms "Section Twenty-nine of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms") confirms the rights of [religious schools](/wiki/Education_in_Canada#Religious_schools "Education in Canada") are preserved.
    [Section 30:](/wiki/Section_Thirty_of_the_Canadian_Charter_of_Rights_and_Freedoms "Section Thirty of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms") clarifies the applicability of the Charter in the territories.
    [Section 31:](/wiki/Section_Thirty-one_of_the_Canadian_Charter_of_Rights_and_Freedoms "Section Thirty-one of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms") confirms that the Charter does not extend the powers of legislatures.

Finally, [Section 34:](/wiki/Section_Thirty-
four_of_the_Canadian_Charter_of_Rights_and_Freedoms "Section Thirty-four of
the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms") states that Part I of the
Constitution Act, 1982, containing the first 34 sections of the Act, may be
collectively referred to as the "Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms".

##
History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Canadian_Charter_of_Rights_and_Freedoms&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: History")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Every_Canadian_Needs_A_Copy.jpg/250px-
Every_Canadian_Needs_A_Copy.jpg)](/wiki/File:Every_Canadian_Needs_A_Copy.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Every_Canadian_Needs_A_Copy.jpg "Enlarge")

Printed copies of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms

Many of the rights and freedoms that are protected under the Charter,
including the rights to [freedom of speech](/wiki/Freedom_of_speech "Freedom
of speech"), [habeas corpus](/wiki/Habeas_corpus "Habeas corpus") and the
[presumption of innocence](/wiki/Presumption_of_innocence "Presumption of
innocence"),[8] have their roots in a set of Canadian laws and legal
precedents[9] sometimes known as the [Implied Bill of
Rights](/wiki/Implied_Bill_of_Rights "Implied Bill of Rights"). Many of these
rights were also included in the [Canadian Bill of
Rights](/wiki/Canadian_Bill_of_Rights "Canadian Bill of Rights"), which the
[Canadian Parliament](/wiki/Parliament_of_Canada "Parliament of Canada")
enacted in 1960. However, the Canadian Bill of Rights had a number of
shortcomings. Unlike the Charter, it was an ordinary Act of Parliament, which
could be amended by a simple majority of Parliament, and it was applicable
only to the federal government. The courts also chose to interpret the Bill of
Rights conservatively, only on rare occasions applying it to find a contrary
law inoperative. The Bill of Rights did not contain all of the rights that are
now included in the Charter, omitting, for instance, the [right to
vote](/wiki/Suffrage "Suffrage")[10] and [freedom of
movement](/wiki/Freedom_of_movement "Freedom of movement") within Canada.[11]

The centennial of [Canadian Confederation](/wiki/Canadian_Confederation
"Canadian Confederation") in 1967 aroused greater interest within the
government in constitutional reform. Said reforms would include improving
safeguards of rights, as well as [patriation](/wiki/Patriation "Patriation")
of the Constitution, meaning the [British
Parliament](/wiki/Parliament_of_the_United_Kingdom "Parliament of the United
Kingdom") would no longer have to approve [constitutional
amendments](/wiki/Constitutional_amendment "Constitutional amendment").
Subsequently, [Attorney General](/wiki/Attorney_General_of_Canada "Attorney
General of Canada") [Pierre Trudeau](/wiki/Pierre_Trudeau "Pierre Trudeau")
appointed law professor [Barry Strayer](/wiki/Barry_Strayer "Barry Strayer")
to research a potential bill of rights. While writing his report, Strayer
consulted with a number of notable legal scholars, including [Walter
Tarnopolsky](/wiki/Walter_Tarnopolsky "Walter Tarnopolsky"). Strayer's report
advocated a number of ideas that were later incorporated into the Charter,
including protection for language rights. Strayer also advocated excluding
economic rights. Finally, he recommended allowing for limits on rights. Such
limits are included in the Charter's limitation and notwithstanding
clauses.[12] In 1968, Strayer was made the Director of the Constitutional Law
Division of the Privy Council Office and in 1974 he became Assistant Deputy
Minister of Justice. During those years, Strayer played a role in writing the
bill that was ultimately adopted.

Meanwhile, Trudeau, who had become [Liberal](/wiki/Liberal_Party_of_Canada
"Liberal Party of Canada") leader and prime minister in 1968, still very much
wanted a constitutional bill of rights. The federal government and the
[provinces](/wiki/Provinces_and_territories_of_Canada "Provinces and
territories of Canada") discussed creating one during negotiations for
patriation, which resulted in the [Victoria Charter](/wiki/Victoria_Charter
"Victoria Charter") in 1971. This never came to be implemented. However,
Trudeau continued with his efforts to patriate the Constitution, and promised
constitutional change during the [1980 Quebec
referendum](/wiki/1980_Quebec_referendum "1980 Quebec referendum"). He would
succeed in 1982 with the passage of the [Canada Act
1982](/wiki/Canada_Act_1982 "Canada Act 1982"). This enacted the Constitution
Act, 1982.

The inclusion of a charter of rights in the Constitution Act was a much-
debated issue. Trudeau spoke on television in October 1980,[13] and announced
his intention to constitutionalize a bill of rights that would include
fundamental freedoms, democratic guarantees, freedom of movement, legal
rights, [equality](/wiki/Social_equality "Social equality") and language
rights.[14] He did not want a notwithstanding clause. While his proposal
gained popular support,[15] provincial leaders opposed the potential limits on
their powers. The federal [Progressive
Conservative](/wiki/Progressive_Conservative_Party_of_Canada "Progressive
Conservative Party of Canada") opposition feared liberal bias among judges,
should courts be called upon to enforce rights.[16] Additionally, the British
Parliament cited their right to uphold Canada's old form of government.[17] At
a suggestion of the Conservatives, Trudeau's government thus agreed to a
committee of [Senators](/wiki/Canadian_Senate "Canadian Senate") and MPs to
further examine the bill of rights as well as the patriation plan. During this
time, 90 hours were spent on the bill of rights alone, all filmed for
television,[15] while civil rights experts and [advocacy
groups](/wiki/Advocacy_group "Advocacy group") put forward their perceptions
on the Charter's flaws and omissions and how to remedy them.[15] As Canada had
a parliamentary system of government, and as judges were perceived not to have
enforced rights well in the past, it was questioned whether the courts should
be named as the enforcers of the Charter, as Trudeau wanted. Conservatives
argued that elected politicians should be trusted instead. It was eventually
decided that the responsibility should go to the courts. At the urging of
[civil libertarians](/wiki/Civil_libertarian "Civil libertarian"), judges
could even now exclude evidence in trials if acquired in breach of Charter
rights in certain circumstances, something the Charter was not originally
going to provide for. As the process continued, more features were added to
the Charter, including equality rights for people with disabilities, more sex
equality guarantees and recognition of Canada's
[multiculturalism](/wiki/Multiculturalism "Multiculturalism"). The limitations
clause was also reworded to focus less on the importance of parliamentary
government and more on justifiability of limits in free societies; the latter
logic was more in line with rights developments around the world after World
War II.[18]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Pierre_Elliot_Trudeau-2.jpg/220px-
Pierre_Elliot_Trudeau-2.jpg)](/wiki/File:Pierre_Elliot_Trudeau-2.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Pierre_Elliot_Trudeau-2.jpg "Enlarge")

[Prime Minister](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Canada "Prime Minister of Canada")
[Pierre Trudeau](/wiki/Pierre_Trudeau "Pierre Trudeau") was a major advocate
of the Charter.

In its decision in the _[Patriation Reference](/wiki/Patriation_Reference
"Patriation Reference")_ (1981), the [Supreme Court of
Canada](/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_Canada "Supreme Court of Canada") had ruled
there was a tradition that some provincial approval should be sought for
constitutional reform. As the provinces still had doubts about the Charter's
merits, Trudeau was forced to accept the notwithstanding clause to allow
governments to opt out of certain obligations. The notwithstanding clause was
accepted as part of a deal called the Kitchen Accord, negotiated by the
federal Attorney General [Jean Chrétien](/wiki/Jean_Chr%C3%A9tien "Jean
Chrétien"), Ontario's justice minister [Roy McMurtry](/wiki/Roy_McMurtry "Roy
McMurtry") and Saskatchewan's justice minister [Roy Romanow](/wiki/Roy_Romanow
"Roy Romanow"). Pressure from provincial governments (which in Canada have
jurisdiction over property) and from the country's [left wing](/wiki/Left-
wing_politics "Left-wing politics"), especially the [New Democratic
Party](/wiki/New_Democratic_Party_\(Canada\) "New Democratic Party
\(Canada\)"), also prevented Trudeau from including any rights protecting
private property.[19]

Nevertheless, Quebec did not support the Charter (or the Canada Act 1982),
with "conflicting interpretations" as to why. The opposition could have owed
to the _[Parti Québécois](/wiki/Parti_Qu%C3%A9b%C3%A9cois "Parti Québécois")_
leadership being allegedly uncooperative, because it was more committed to
gaining sovereignty for Quebec. It could have owed to Quebec leaders being
excluded from the negotiation of the [Kitchen Accord](/wiki/Kitchen_Accord
"Kitchen Accord"), which they saw as being too centralist. It could have owed
to provincial leaders' objections to the Accord's provisions relating to the
process of future constitutional amendment.[20] They also opposed the
inclusion of mobility rights and minority language education rights.[21] The
Charter is still applicable in Quebec because all provinces are bound by the
Constitution. However, Quebec's opposition to the 1982 patriation package has
led to two failed attempts to amend the Constitution (the [Meech Lake
Accord](/wiki/Meech_Lake_Accord "Meech Lake Accord") and [Charlottetown
Accord](/wiki/Charlottetown_Accord "Charlottetown Accord")) which were
designed primarily to obtain Quebec's political approval of the Canadian
constitutional order.

While the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms was adopted in 1982, it was
not until 1985 that the main provisions regarding equality rights (section 15)
came into effect. The delay was meant to give the federal and provincial
governments an opportunity to review pre-existing statutes and strike
potentially unconstitutional inequalities.

The typography of the physical document pictured here, and still distributed
today, was typeset by Ottawa's [David
Berman](/wiki/David_Berman_\(graphic_designer\) "David Berman \(graphic
designer\)") intentionally in Carl Dair's [Cartier](/wiki/Cartier_\(typeface\)
"Cartier \(typeface\)") typeface: at the time the most prominent Canadian
typeface, having been commissioned by the Governor-General as a celebration of
Canada's centenary in 1967.

The Charter has been amended since its enactment. Section 25 was amended in
1983 to explicitly recognize more rights regarding [Aboriginal land
claims](/wiki/Aboriginal_land_claims "Aboriginal land claims"), and section
16.1 was added in 1993. There have also been a number of [unsuccessful
attempts to amend the
Charter](/wiki/Unsuccessful_attempts_to_amend_the_Canadian_Constitution
"Unsuccessful attempts to amend the Canadian Constitution"), including the
failed [Charlottetown Accord](/wiki/Charlottetown_Accord "Charlottetown
Accord") of 1992. The Charlottetown Accord would have specifically required
the Charter to be interpreted in a manner respectful of Quebec's [distinct
society](/wiki/Distinct_society "Distinct society"), and would have added
further statements to the [Constitution Act,
1867](/wiki/Constitution_Act,_1867 "Constitution Act, 1867") regarding racial
and sexual equality and collective rights, and about [minority
language](/wiki/Minority_language "Minority language") communities. Though the
Accord was negotiated among many interest groups, the resulting provisions
were so vague that Trudeau, then out of office, feared they would actually
conflict with and undermine the Charter's individual rights. He felt judicial
review of the rights might be undermined if courts had to favour the policies
of provincial governments, as governments would be given responsibility over
linguistic minorities. Trudeau thus played a prominent role in leading the
popular opposition to the Accord.[22]

## Interpretation and
enforcement[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Canadian_Charter_of_Rights_and_Freedoms&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Interpretation and enforcement")]

The task of interpreting and enforcing the Charter falls to the courts, with
the Supreme Court of Canada being the ultimate authority on the matter.

With the Charter's supremacy confirmed by section 52 of the Constitution Act,
1982, the courts continued their practice of striking down unconstitutional
statutes or parts of statutes as they had with earlier case law regarding
federalism. However, under section 24 of the Charter, courts also gained new
powers to enforce creative remedies and exclude more evidence in trials.
Courts have since made many important decisions, including _[R. v.
Morgentaler](/wiki/R._v._Morgentaler "R. v. Morgentaler")_ (1988), which
struck down [Canada's abortion law](/wiki/Abortion_in_Canada "Abortion in
Canada"), and _[Vriend v. Alberta](/wiki/Vriend_v._Alberta "Vriend v.
Alberta")_ (1998), in which the Supreme Court found the province's exclusion
of [homosexuals](/wiki/Homosexuality "Homosexuality") from protection against
discrimination violated section 15. In the latter case, the Court then read
the protection into the law.

Courts may receive Charter questions in a number of ways. Rights claimants
could be prosecuted under a [criminal law](/wiki/Criminal_law_in_Canada
"Criminal law in Canada") that they argue is unconstitutional. Others may feel
government services and policies are not being dispensed in accordance with
the Charter, and apply to lower-level courts for injunctions against the
government (as was the case in _[Doucet-Boudreau v. Nova Scotia (Minister of
Education)](/wiki/Doucet-Boudreau_v._Nova_Scotia_\(Minister_of_Education\)
"Doucet-Boudreau v. Nova Scotia \(Minister of Education\)")_). A government
may also raise questions of rights by submitting [reference
questions](/wiki/Reference_question "Reference question") to higher-level
courts; for example, Prime Minister [Paul Martin](/wiki/Paul_Martin "Paul
Martin")'s government approached the Supreme Court with Charter questions as
well as federalism concerns in the case _[Re Same-Sex Marriage](/wiki/Re_Same-
Sex_Marriage "Re Same-Sex Marriage")_ (2004). Provinces may also do this with
their superior courts. The government of [Prince Edward
Island](/wiki/Prince_Edward_Island "Prince Edward Island") initiated the
_[Provincial Judges Reference](/wiki/Provincial_Judges_Reference "Provincial
Judges Reference")_ by asking its [provincial Supreme Court](/wiki/PESCAD
"PESCAD") a question on [judicial independence](/wiki/Judicial_independence
"Judicial independence") under section 11.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Ottawa_-_ON_-
_Oberster_Gerichtshof_von_Kanada.jpg/250px-Ottawa_-_ON_-
_Oberster_Gerichtshof_von_Kanada.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ottawa_-_ON_-
_Oberster_Gerichtshof_von_Kanada.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Ottawa_-_ON_-_Oberster_Gerichtshof_von_Kanada.jpg "Enlarge")

The building of the [Supreme Court of Canada](/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_Canada
"Supreme Court of Canada"), the chief authority on the interpretation of the
Charter

In several important cases, judges developed various tests and precedents for
interpreting specific provisions of the Charter. These include the _Oakes
test_ for section 1, set out in the case _[R. v. Oakes](/wiki/R._v._Oakes "R.
v. Oakes")_ (1986), and the (now defunct[23]) _Law test_ for section 15,
developed in _[Law v. Canada](/wiki/Law_v._Canada "Law v. Canada")_ (1999).
Since _[Re B.C. Motor Vehicle Act](/wiki/Re_B.C._Motor_Vehicle_Act "Re B.C.
Motor Vehicle Act")_ (1985), various approaches to defining and expanding the
scope of [fundamental justice](/wiki/Fundamental_justice "Fundamental
justice") (the Canadian name for [natural justice](/wiki/Natural_justice
"Natural justice") or [due process](/wiki/Due_process "Due process")) under
section 7 have been adopted. (_For more information, see the[articles on each
Charter section](/wiki/Category:Canadian_Charter_of_Rights_and_Freedoms
"Category:Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms")_).

In general, courts have embraced a _[purposive
interpretation](/wiki/Purposive_interpretation "Purposive interpretation")_ of
Charter rights.[24] This means that since early cases like _[Hunter v.
Southam](/wiki/Hunter_v._Southam "Hunter v. Southam")_ (1984) and _[R. v. Big
M Drug Mart](/wiki/R._v._Big_M_Drug_Mart "R. v. Big M Drug Mart")_ (1985),
they have concentrated not on the traditional, limited understanding of what
each right meant when the Charter was adopted in 1982, but rather on changing
the scope of rights as appropriate to fit their broader purpose.[24] This is
tied to the _generous interpretation_ of rights, as the purpose of the Charter
provisions is assumed to be to increase rights and freedoms of people in a
variety of circumstances, at the expense of the government powers.[24]
Constitutional scholar [Peter Hogg](/wiki/Peter_Hogg "Peter Hogg") has
approved of the generous approach in some cases, although for others he argues
the purpose of the provisions was not to achieve a set of rights as broad as
courts have imagined.[24] Indeed, this approach has not been without its
critics. Alberta politician [Ted Morton](/wiki/Ted_Morton "Ted Morton") and
political scientist [Rainer Knopff](/wiki/Rainer_Knopff "Rainer Knopff") have
been very critical of this phenomenon. Although they feel the basis for the
approach, the [living tree doctrine](/wiki/Living_tree_doctrine "Living tree
doctrine") (the classical name for generous interpretations of the Canadian
Constitution), is sound, they argue Charter case law has been more radical.
When the living tree doctrine is applied right, the authors claim, "The elm
remained an elm; it grew new branches but did not transform itself into an oak
or a willow." The doctrine can be used, for example, so a right is upheld even
when a government threatens to violate it with new technology, as long as the
essential right remains the same; but the authors claim that the courts have
used the doctrine to "create new rights." As an example, the authors note that
the Charter right against [self-incrimination](/wiki/Self-incrimination "Self-
incrimination") has been extended to cover scenarios in the justice system
that had previously been unregulated by self-incrimination rights in other
Canadian laws.[25]

Another general approach to interpreting Charter rights is to consider
international legal precedents with countries that have specific rights
protections, such as the [United States Bill of
Rights](/wiki/United_States_Bill_of_Rights "United States Bill of Rights") (an
influence on aspects of the Charter) and the [Constitution of South
Africa](/wiki/Constitution_of_South_Africa "Constitution of South Africa").
However, international precedent is only of guiding value, and is not binding.
For example, the Supreme Court has referred to the Charter and the American
Bill of Rights as being "born to different countries in different ages and in
different circumstances."[26]

Public interest groups frequently [intervene](/wiki/Intervention_\(law\)
"Intervention \(law\)") in cases to make arguments on how to interpret the
Charter. Some examples are the [British Columbia Civil Liberties
Association](/wiki/British_Columbia_Civil_Liberties_Association "British
Columbia Civil Liberties Association"), [Canadian Civil Liberties
Association](/wiki/Canadian_Civil_Liberties_Association "Canadian Civil
Liberties Association"), the [Canadian Mental Health
Association](/wiki/Canadian_Mental_Health_Association "Canadian Mental Health
Association"), the [Canadian Labour Congress](/wiki/Canadian_Labour_Congress
"Canadian Labour Congress"), the [Women's Legal Education and Action
Fund](/wiki/Women%27s_Legal_Education_and_Action_Fund "Women's Legal Education
and Action Fund") (LEAF), and [REAL Women of
Canada](/wiki/REAL_Women_of_Canada "REAL Women of Canada"). The purpose of
such interventions is to assist the court and to attempt to influence the
court to render a decision favourable to the legal interests of the group.

A further approach to the Charter, taken by the courts, is the [dialogue
principle](/wiki/Dialogue_principle "Dialogue principle"), which involves
greater participation by elected governments. This approach involves
governments drafting legislation in response to court rulings and courts
acknowledging the effort if the new legislation is challenged.

## Comparisons with other human rights
documents[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Canadian_Charter_of_Rights_and_Freedoms&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Comparisons with other human rights documents")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Bill_of_Rights_Pg1of1_AC.jpg/220px-
Bill_of_Rights_Pg1of1_AC.jpg)](/wiki/File:Bill_of_Rights_Pg1of1_AC.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Bill_of_Rights_Pg1of1_AC.jpg "Enlarge")

The [United States Bill of Rights](/wiki/United_States_Bill_of_Rights "United
States Bill of Rights") influenced the text of the Charter, but its rights
provisions are interpreted more conservatively. Canadian civil-rights and
constitutional cases as compared to American cases occasionally have
dissimilar outcomes because the broader Charter rights are limited by the
"savings clause" of [section 1 of the
Charter](/wiki/Section_One_of_the_Canadian_Charter_of_Rights_and_Freedoms
"Section One of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms") as interpreted
in _[R. v. Oakes](/wiki/R._v._Oakes "R. v. Oakes")_

Some Canadian [Members of Parliament](/wiki/Member_of_Parliament "Member of
Parliament") saw the movement to entrench a charter as contrary to the British
model of [Parliamentary supremacy](/wiki/Parliamentary_supremacy
"Parliamentary supremacy"). Others would say that the [European Convention on
Human Rights](/wiki/European_Convention_on_Human_Rights "European Convention
on Human Rights") (ECHR) has now limited British parliamentary power to a
greater degree than the Canadian Charter limited the power of the Canadian
Parliament and provincial legislatures. Hogg has speculated that the British
adopted the [Human Rights Act 1998](/wiki/Human_Rights_Act_1998 "Human Rights
Act 1998"), which allows the [ECHR](/wiki/ECHR "ECHR") to be enforced directly
in domestic courts, partly because they were inspired by the similar Canadian
Charter.[27]

The Canadian Charter bears a number of similarities to the European
Convention, specifically in relation to the limitations clauses contained in
the European document.[28] Because of this similarity with European human
rights law, the Supreme Court of Canada turns not only to the [Constitution of
the United States](/wiki/Constitution_of_the_United_States "Constitution of
the United States") case law in interpreting the Charter, but also to
[European Court of Human Rights](/wiki/European_Court_of_Human_Rights
"European Court of Human Rights") cases.

The core distinction between the United States Bill of Rights and Canadian
Charter is the existence of the limitations and notwithstanding clauses.
Canadian courts have consequently interpreted each right more expansively.[29]
However, due to the limitations clause, where a violation of a right exists,
the law will not necessarily grant protection of that right.[29] In contrast,
rights under the US Bill of Rights are absolute and so a violation will not be
found until there has been sufficient encroachment on those rights. The sum
effect is that both constitutions provide comparable protection of many
rights.[29] Fundamental justice (in section 7 of the Canadian Charter) is
therefore interpreted to include more legal protections than due process,
which is its US equivalent. Freedom of expression in section 2 also has a more
wide-ranging scope than the [First Amendment to the United States
Constitution](/wiki/First_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution "First
Amendment to the United States Constitution")'s freedom of speech.[29] In
_[RWDSU v. Dolphin Delivery Ltd.](/wiki/RWDSU_v._Dolphin_Delivery_Ltd. "RWDSU
v. Dolphin Delivery Ltd.")_ (1986), the Canadian Supreme Court considered
[picketing](/wiki/Picketing_\(protest\) "Picketing \(protest\)") of the kind
the US First Amendment did not permit, as it was disruptive conduct (though
there was some speech involved that the First Amendment might otherwise
protect). The Supreme Court, however, ruled the picketing, including the
disruptive conduct, were fully protected under section 2 of the Charter. The
Court then relied on section 1 to find the injunction against the picketing
was just.[30] The limitations clause has also allowed governments to enact
laws that would be considered unconstitutional in the US. The Supreme Court of
Canada has upheld some of Quebec's limits on the use of
[English](/wiki/English_language "English language") on signs and has upheld
[publication bans](/wiki/Publication_ban "Publication ban") that prohibit
media from mentioning the names of juvenile criminals.

Section 28 of the Charter performs a function similar to that of the
unratified [Equal Rights Amendment](/wiki/Equal_Rights_Amendment "Equal Rights
Amendment") in the US. While that proposed amendment had many critics, there
was no comparable opposition to the Charter's section 28.[31] Still, Canadian
feminists had to stage large protests to demonstrate support for the inclusion
of the section which had not been part of the original draft of the
charter.[32][33]

The [International Covenant on Civil and Political
Rights](/wiki/International_Covenant_on_Civil_and_Political_Rights
"International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights") has several parallels
with the Canadian Charter, but in some cases the Covenant goes further with
regard to rights in its text. For example, a right to [legal
aid](/wiki/Legal_aid "Legal aid") has been read into section 10 of the Charter
(the right to counsel), but the Covenant explicitly guarantees the accused
need not pay "if he does not have sufficient means."[34]

The Canadian Charter has little to say, explicitly at least, about economic
and social rights. On this point, it stands in marked contrast with the
[Quebec Charter of Human Rights and
Freedoms](/wiki/Quebec_Charter_of_Human_Rights_and_Freedoms "Quebec Charter of
Human Rights and Freedoms") and with the [International Covenant on Economic,
Social and Cultural
Rights](/wiki/International_Covenant_on_Economic,_Social_and_Cultural_Rights
"International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights"). There are
some who feel economic rights ought to be read into section 7 rights to
[security of the person](/wiki/Security_of_the_person "Security of the
person") and section 15 equality rights to make the Charter similar to the
Covenant.[32] The rationale is that economic rights can relate to a decent
[standard of living](/wiki/Standard_of_living "Standard of living") and can
help the civil rights flourish in a livable environment.[32] Canadian courts,
however, have been hesitant in this area, stating that economic rights are
[political questions](/wiki/Political_question "Political question") and
adding that as [positive rights](/wiki/Negative_and_positive_rights "Negative
and positive rights"), economic rights are of questionable legitimacy.[32]

The Charter itself influenced the [Bill of
Rights](/wiki/Constitution_of_South_Africa_Chapter_2:_Bill_of_Rights
"Constitution of South Africa Chapter 2: Bill of Rights") in the Constitution
of South Africa.[32] The limitations clause under section 36 of the South
African law has been compared to section 1 of that _Charter_.[28]

[Jamaica](/wiki/Jamaica "Jamaica")'s Charter of Fundamental Rights and
Freedoms was also influenced, in part, by the Canadian charter.[35][36]

## The Charter and national
values[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Canadian_Charter_of_Rights_and_Freedoms&action=edit&section=14
"Edit section: The Charter and national values")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/March_of_Hearts_crowd_on_Parliament_Hill_2004.jpg/250px-
March_of_Hearts_crowd_on_Parliament_Hill_2004.jpg)](/wiki/File:March_of_Hearts_crowd_on_Parliament_Hill_2004.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:March_of_Hearts_crowd_on_Parliament_Hill_2004.jpg "Enlarge")

The "March of Hearts" rally for [same-sex marriage](/wiki/Same-
sex_marriage_in_Canada "Same-sex marriage in Canada") equality under the
Charter in 2004.

The Charter was intended to be a source for [Canadian
values](/wiki/Canadian_values "Canadian values") and national unity. As
Professor [Alan Cairns](/wiki/Alan_Cairns "Alan Cairns") noted, "The initial
federal government premise was on developing a pan-Canadian identity."[27]
Trudeau himself later wrote in his _Memoirs_ that "Canada itself" could now be
defined as a "society where all people are equal and where they share some
fundamental values based upon freedom", and that all Canadians could identify
with the values of liberty and equality.[37]

The Charter's unifying purpose was particularly important to the mobility and
language rights. According to author [Rand Dyck](/wiki/Rand_Dyck "Rand Dyck"),
some scholars believe section 23, with its minority language education rights,
"was the only part of the Charter with which Pierre Trudeau was truly
concerned".[38] Through the mobility and language rights, [French
Canadians](/wiki/French_Canadian "French Canadian"), who have been at the
centre of unity debates, are able to travel throughout all Canada and receive
government and educational services in their own language. Hence, they are not
confined to Quebec (the only province where they form the majority and where
most of their population is based), which would polarize the country along
regional lines. The Charter was also supposed to standardize previously
diverse laws throughout the country and gear them towards a single principle
of liberty.[39]

Former [premier of Ontario](/wiki/Premier_of_Ontario "Premier of Ontario")
[Bob Rae](/wiki/Bob_Rae "Bob Rae") has stated that the Charter "functions as a
symbol for all Canadians" in practice because it represents the core value of
freedom.[27] Academic [Peter Russell](/wiki/Peter_H._Russell "Peter H.
Russell") has been more skeptical of the Charter's value in this field.
Cairns, who feels the Charter is the most important constitutional document to
many Canadians, and that the Charter was meant to shape the Canadian identity,
has also expressed concern that groups within society see certain provisions
as belonging to them alone rather than to all Canadians.[27] It has also been
noted that issues like [abortion](/wiki/Abortion "Abortion") and
[pornography](/wiki/Pornography "Pornography"), raised by the Charter, tend to
be controversial.[39] Still, [opinion polls](/wiki/Opinion_polls "Opinion
polls") in 2002 showed Canadians felt the Charter significantly represented
Canada, although many were unaware of the document's actual contents.[40]

The only values mentioned by the [Charter's
preamble](/wiki/Preamble_to_the_Canadian_Charter_of_Rights_and_Freedoms
"Preamble to the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms") are recognition for
the supremacy of [God](/wiki/Constitutional_references_to_God "Constitutional
references to God") and the [rule of law](/wiki/Rule_of_law "Rule of law"),
but these have been controversial and of minor legal consequence. In 1999, MP
[Svend Robinson](/wiki/Svend_Robinson "Svend Robinson") brought forward a
failed proposal before the [Canadian House of
Commons](/wiki/Canadian_House_of_Commons "Canadian House of Commons") that
would have amended the Charter by removing the mention of God, as he felt it
did not reflect Canada's diversity.

Section 27 also recognizes a value of multiculturalism. In 2002, polls found
86% of Canadians approved of this section.[41]

##
Criticism[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Canadian_Charter_of_Rights_and_Freedoms&action=edit&section=15
"Edit section: Criticism")]

While the Charter has enjoyed a great deal of popularity, with 82% of
Canadians describing it as a good thing in opinion polls in 1987 and 1999,[27]
the document has also been subject to published criticisms from both sides of
the political spectrum. One left-wing critic is Professor [Michael
Mandel](/wiki/Michael_Mandel_\(law_professor\) "Michael Mandel \(law
professor\)"), who wrote that in comparison to politicians, judges do not have
to be as sensitive to the will of the electorate, nor do they have to make
sure their decisions are easily understandable to the average Canadian
citizen. This, in Mandel's view, limits democracy.[42] Mandel has also
asserted that the Charter makes Canada more like the United States, especially
by serving corporate rights and [individual rights](/wiki/Individual_rights
"Individual rights") rather than group rights and social rights.[42] He has
argued that there are several things that should be included in the Charter,
such as a right to health care and a basic right to free education. Hence, the
perceived [Americanization](/wiki/Americanization "Americanization") of
Canadian politics is seen as coming at the expense of values more important
for Canadians.[42] The union movement has been disappointed in the reluctance
of the courts to use the Charter to support various forms of union activity,
such as the "right to strike".

Right-wing critics Morton and Knopff have raised several concerns about the
Charter, notably by alleging that the federal government has used it to limit
provincial powers by allying with various rights claimants and interest
groups. In their book _The Charter Revolution & the Court Party_, Morton and
Knopff express their suspicions of this alliance in detail, accusing the
Trudeau and Chrétien governments of funding litigious groups. For example,
these governments used the [Court Challenges
Program](/wiki/Court_Challenges_Program_of_Canada "Court Challenges Program of
Canada") to support minority language educational rights claims. Morton and
Knopff also assert that [crown counsel](/wiki/Crown_attorney "Crown attorney")
has intentionally lost cases in which the government was taken to court for
allegedly violating rights, particularly [gay rights](/wiki/Gay_rights "Gay
rights") and [women's rights](/wiki/Women%27s_rights "Women's rights").[43]

Political scientist Rand Dyck, in observing these criticisms, notes that while
judges have had their scope of review widened, they have still upheld most
laws challenged on Charter grounds. With regard to litigious interest groups,
Dyck points out that "the record is not as clear as Morton and Knopff imply.
All such groups have experienced wins and losses."[44]

The political philosopher [Charles
Blattberg](/w/index.php?title=Charles_Blattberg&action=edit&redlink=1 "Charles
Blattberg \(page does not exist\)") has criticized the Charter for
contributing to the fragmentation of the country, at both the individual and
group levels. In encouraging discourse based upon rights, the Charter is said
to inject an adversarial spirit into Canadian politics, making it difficult to
realize the common good. Blattberg also claims that the Charter undercuts the
Canadian political community since it is ultimately a cosmopolitan document.
Finally, he argues that people would be more motivated to uphold individual
liberties if they were expressed with terms that are much "thicker" (less
abstract) than rights.[45]
